qas.question: Following the war, why did some military airfields add civil facilities?
Which airport near Paris was one of the first to add civil facilities for handling passenger traffic?
What was the first airport to operate scheduled international commercial services?
When did the Hounslow Heath Aerodrome begin to operate scheduled international commercial services?
What did airports use to permit night flying as well as landing heavier aircraft?
When was the Paris - Le Bourget Airport first opened?
What was the Paris - Le Bourget Airport replaced by?
When did Houndlow Heath Aerodrome replace Croydon Airport?
When was Croydon Airport opened in Flughafen Devau?
What was used at military airfields in 1919?

context: Following the war, some of these military airfields added civil facilities <a0_0>for handling passenger traffic<a0_0/>. One of the earliest such fields was Paris – <a1_0>Le Bourget Airport<a1_0/> at Le Bourget, near Paris. The first airport to operate scheduled international commercial services was <a2_0>Hounslow Heath Aerodrome<a2_0/> in <a3_0><b5_0>August 1919<b5_0/><a3_0/>, but it was closed and supplanted by <b6_0>Croydon Airport<b6_0/> in <b7_0>March 1920<b7_0/>. <b8_0>In 1922<b8_0/>, the first permanent airport and commercial terminal solely for commercial aviation was opened at Flughafen Devau near what was then Königsberg, East Prussia. The airports of this era used <a4_0><b9_0>a paved "apron"<b9_0/><a4_0/>, which permitted night flying as well as landing heavier aircraft.
